properties.name: response_id
properties.description: The ID of the Response to which the item belongs.

properties.name: output_index
properties.description: The index of the output item in the Response.

properties.name: item
properties.description: The item to add to the conversation.

properties.name: id
properties.description:
The unique ID of the item, this can be generated by the client to help 
manage server-side context, but is not required because the server will 
generate one if not provided.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The type of the item (`message`, `function_call`, `function_call_output`).

properties.name: object
properties.description: Identifier for the API object being returned - always `realtime.item`.

properties.name: status
properties.description:
The status of the item (`completed`, `incomplete`). These have no effect 
on the conversation, but are accepted for consistency with the 
`conversation.item.created` event.

properties.name: role
properties.description:
The role of the message sender (`user`, `assistant`, `system`), only 
applicable for `message` items.

properties.name: content
properties.description:
The content of the message, applicable for `message` items. 
- Message items of role `system` support only `input_text` content
- Message items of role `user` support `input_text` and `input_audio` 
  content
- Message items of role `assistant` support `text` content.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The content type (`input_text`, `input_audio`, `item_reference`, `text`).

properties.name: text
properties.description: The text content, used for `input_text` and `text` content types.

properties.name: id
properties.description:
ID of a previous conversation item to reference (for `item_reference`
content types in `response.create` events). These can reference both
client and server created items.

properties.name: audio
properties.description: Base64-encoded audio bytes, used for `input_audio` content type.

properties.name: transcript
properties.description: The transcript of the audio, used for `input_audio` content type.

properties.name: call_id
properties.description:
The ID of the function call (for `function_call` and 
`function_call_output` items). If passed on a `function_call_output` 
item, the server will check that a `function_call` item with the same 
ID exists in the conversation history.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The name of the function being called (for `function_call` items).

properties.name: arguments
properties.description: The arguments of the function call (for `function_call` items).

properties.name: output
properties.description: The output of the function call (for `function_call_output` items).

title: response.content_part.added
description:
Returned when a new content part is added to an assistant message item during
response generation.

properties.name: event_id
properties.description: The unique ID of the server event.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The event type, must be `response.content_part.added`.

properties.name: response_id
properties.description: The ID of the response.

properties.name: item_id
properties.description: The ID of the item to which the content part was added.

properties.name: output_index
properties.description: The index of the output item in the response.

properties.name: content_index
properties.description: The index of the content part in the item's content array.

properties.name: part
properties.description: The content part that was added.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The content type ("text", "audio").

properties.name: text
properties.description: The text content (if type is "text").

properties.name: audio
properties.description: Base64-encoded audio data (if type is "audio").

properties.name: transcript
properties.description: The transcript of the audio (if type is "audio").

title: response.content_part.done
description:
Returned when a content part is done streaming in an assistant message item.
Also emitted when a Response is interrupted, incomplete, or cancelled.

properties.name: event_id
properties.description: The unique ID of the server event.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The event type, must be `response.content_part.done`.

properties.name: response_id
properties.description: The ID of the response.

properties.name: item_id
properties.description: The ID of the item.

properties.name: output_index
properties.description: The index of the output item in the response.

properties.name: content_index
properties.description: The index of the content part in the item's content array.

properties.name: part
properties.description: The content part that is done.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The content type ("text", "audio").

properties.name: text
properties.description: The text content (if type is "text").

properties.name: audio
properties.description: Base64-encoded audio data (if type is "audio").

properties.name: transcript

title: response.text.delta
description: Returned when the text value of a "text" content part is updated.

properties.name: event_id

properties.name: response_id

properties.description: The index of the content part in the item's content array.

properties.name: delta

title: transcription_session.updated
description:
Returned when a transcription session is updated with a `transcription_session.update` event, unless 
there is an error.

properties.name: event_id
properties.description: The unique ID of the server event.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The event type, must be `transcription_session.updated`.

properties.name: session
properties.description:
A new Realtime transcription session configuration.

When a session is created on the server via REST API, the session object
also contains an ephemeral key. Default TTL for keys is one minute. This 
property is not present when a session is updated via the WebSocket API.

properties.name: client_secret
properties.description:
Ephemeral key returned by the API. Only present when the session is
created on the server via REST API.

properties.name: value
properties.description:
Ephemeral key usable in client environments to authenticate connections
to the Realtime API. Use this in client-side environments rather than
a standard API token, which should only be used server-side.

properties.name: expires_at
properties.description:
Timestamp for when the token expires. Currently, all tokens expire
after one minute.

properties.name: modalities
properties.description:
The set of modalities the model can respond with. To disable audio,
set this to ["text"].

properties.name: input_audio_format
properties.description: The format of input audio. Options are `pcm16`, `g711_ulaw`, or `g711_alaw`.

properties.name: input_audio_transcription
properties.description: Configuration of the transcription model.

properties.name: model
properties.description: The model to use for transcription. Can be `gpt-4o-transcribe`, `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe`, or `whisper-1`.

properties.name: language
properties.description:
The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in
[ISO-639-1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_639-1_codes) (e.g. `en`) format
will improve accuracy and latency.

properties.name: prompt
properties.description:
An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio
segment. The [prompt](/docs/guides/speech-to-text#prompting) should match
the audio language.

properties.name: turn_detection
properties.description:
Configuration for turn detection. Can be set to `null` to turn off. Server 
VAD means that the model will detect the start and end of speech based on 
audio volume and respond at the end of user speech.

properties.name: type
properties.description: Type of turn detection, only `server_vad` is currently supported.

properties.name: threshold
properties.description:
Activation threshold for VAD (0.0 to 1.0), this defaults to 0.5. A 
higher threshold will require louder audio to activate the model, and 
thus might perform better in noisy environments.

properties.name: prefix_padding_ms
properties.description:
Amount of audio to include before the VAD detected speech (in 
milliseconds). Defaults to 300ms.

properties.name: silence_duration_ms
properties.description:
Duration of silence to detect speech stop (in milliseconds). Defaults 
to 500ms. With shorter values the model will respond more quickly, 
but may jump in on short pauses from the user.

title: rate_limits.updated
description:
Emitted at the beginning of a Response to indicate the updated rate limits. 
When a Response is created some tokens will be "reserved" for the output 
tokens, the rate limits shown here reflect that reservation, which is then 
adjusted accordingly once the Response is completed.

properties.name: event_id
properties.description: The unique ID of the server event.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The event type, must be `rate_limits.updated`.

properties.name: rate_limits
properties.description: List of rate limit information.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The name of the rate limit (`requests`, `tokens`).

properties.name: limit
properties.description: The maximum allowed value for the rate limit.

properties.name: remaining
properties.description: The remaining value before the limit is reached.

properties.name: reset_seconds
properties.description: Seconds until the rate limit resets.

title: output_audio_buffer.started
description:
**WebRTC Only:** Emitted when the server begins streaming audio to the client. This event is
emitted after an audio content part has been added (`response.content_part.added`)
to the response.
[Learn more](/docs/guides/realtime-model-capabilities#client-and-server-events-for-audio-in-webrtc).

properties.name: event_id
properties.description: The unique ID of the server event.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The event type, must be `output_audio_buffer.started`.

properties.name: response_id
properties.description: The unique ID of the response that produced the audio.

title: output_audio_buffer.stopped
description:
**WebRTC Only:** Emitted when the output audio buffer has been completely drained on the server,
and no more audio is forthcoming. This event is emitted after the full response
data has been sent to the client (`response.done`).
[Learn more](/docs/guides/realtime-model-capabilities#client-and-server-events-for-audio-in-webrtc).

properties.name: event_id
properties.description: The unique ID of the server event.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The event type, must be `output_audio_buffer.stopped`.

properties.name: response_id
properties.description: The unique ID of the response that produced the audio.

title: output_audio_buffer.cleared
description:
**WebRTC Only:** Emitted when the output audio buffer is cleared. This happens either in VAD
mode when the user has interrupted (`input_audio_buffer.speech_started`),
or when the client has emitted the `output_audio_buffer.clear` event to manually
cut off the current audio response.
[Learn more](/docs/guides/realtime-model-capabilities#client-and-server-events-for-audio-in-webrtc).

properties.name: event_id
properties.description: The unique ID of the server event.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The event type, must be `output_audio_buffer.cleared`.

properties.name: response_id
properties.description: The unique ID of the response that produced the audio.

title: Create speech
description:
---
group:
  - Audio
---
Generates audio from the input text.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/audio/speech \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "model": "gpt-4o-mini-tts",
    "input": "The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog.",
    "voice": "alloy"
  }' \
  --output speech.mp3

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from pathlib import Path
import openai

speech_file_path = Path(__file__).parent / "speech.mp3"
with openai.audio.speech.with_streaming_response.create(
  model="gpt-4o-mini-tts",
  voice="alloy",
  input="The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog."
) as response:
  response.stream_to_file(speech_file_path)

tabs.title: javascript
csharp

properties.name: model
properties.description: One of the available [TTS models](/docs/models#tts): `tts-1`, `tts-1-hd` or `gpt-4o-mini-tts`.

properties.name: input
properties.description: The text to generate audio for. The maximum length is 4096 characters.

properties.name: instructions
properties.description: Control the voice of your generated audio with additional instructions. Does not work with `tts-1` or `tts-1-hd`.

properties.name: voice
properties.description: The voice to use when generating the audio. Supported voices are `alloy`, `ash`, `ballad`, `coral`, `echo`, `fable`, `onyx`, `nova`, `sage`, `shimmer`, and `verse`. Previews of the voices are available in the [Text to speech guide](/docs/guides/text-to-speech#voice-options).

properties.name: response_format
properties.description: The format to audio in. Supported formats are `mp3`, `opus`, `aac`, `flac`, `wav`, and `pcm`.

properties.name: speed
properties.description: The speed of the generated audio. Select a value from `0.25` to `4.0`. `1.0` is the default.

title: Create transcription
description:
---
group:
  - Audio
---
Transcribes audio into the input language.

tabs.title: curl
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/audio/transcriptions \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: multipart/form-data" \
  -F file="@/path/to/file/audio.mp3" \
  -F model="gpt-4o-transcribe"

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

audio_file = open("speech.mp3", "rb")
transcript = client.audio.transcriptions.create(
  model="gpt-4o-transcribe",
  file=audio_file
)

tabs.title: javascript
csharp
curl
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/audio/transcriptions \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: multipart/form-data" \
  -F file="@/path/to/file/audio.mp3" \
  -F model="gpt-4o-mini-transcribe" \
  -F stream=true

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

audio_file = open("speech.mp3", "rb")
stream = client.audio.transcriptions.create(
  file=audio_file,
  model="gpt-4o-mini-transcribe",
  stream=True
)

for event in stream:
  print(event)

tabs.title: javascript
curl
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/audio/transcriptions \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: multipart/form-data" \
  -F file="@/path/to/file/audio.mp3" \
  -F "include[]=logprobs" \
  -F model="gpt-4o-transcribe" \
  -F response_format="json"

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

audio_file = open("speech.mp3", "rb")
transcript = client.audio.transcriptions.create(
  file=audio_file,
  model="gpt-4o-transcribe",
  response_format="json",
  include=["logprobs"]
)

print(transcript)

tabs.title: javascript
curl
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/audio/transcriptions \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: multipart/form-data" \
  -F file="@/path/to/file/audio.mp3" \
  -F "timestamp_granularities[]=word" \
  -F model="whisper-1" \
  -F response_format="verbose_json"

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

audio_file = open("speech.mp3", "rb")
transcript = client.audio.transcriptions.create(
  file=audio_file,
  model="whisper-1",
  response_format="verbose_json",
  timestamp_granularities=["word"]
)

print(transcript.words)

tabs.title: javascript
csharp
curl
tabs.code:

  -H "Content-Type: multipart/form-data" \
  -F file="@/path/to/file/audio.mp3" \
  -F "timestamp_granularities[]=segment" \
  -F model="whisper-1" \
  -F response_format="verbose_json"

from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

audio_file = open("speech.mp3", "rb")
transcript = client.audio.transcriptions.create(
  file=audio_file,

tabs.title: javascript
csharp

tabs.code:
{
  "task": "transcribe",
  "language": "english",
  "duration": 8.470000267028809,
  "text": "The beach was a popular spot on a hot summer day. People were swimming in the ocean, building sandcastles, and playing beach volleyball.",
  "segments": [
    {
      "id": 0,
      "seek": 0,
      "start": 0.0,
      "end": 3.319999933242798,
      "text": " The beach was a popular spot on a hot summer day.",
      "tokens": [
        50364, 440, 7534, 390, 257, 3743, 4008, 322, 257, 2368, 4266, 786, 13, 50530
      ],
      "temperature": 0.0,
      "avg_logprob": -0.2860786020755768,
      "compression_ratio": 1.2363636493682861,
      "no_speech_prob": 0.00985979475080967
    },
    ...
  ]
}

properties.name: file
properties.description: The audio file object (not file name) to transcribe, in one of these formats: flac, mp3, mp4, mpeg, mpga, m4a, ogg, wav, or webm.

properties.name: model
properties.description: ID of the model to use. The options are `gpt-4o-transcribe`, `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe`, and `whisper-1` (which is powered by our open source Whisper V2 model).

properties.name: language
properties.description: The language of the input audio. Supplying the input language in [ISO-639-1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_639-1_codes) (e.g. `en`) format will improve accuracy and latency.

properties.name: prompt
properties.description: An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio segment. The [prompt](/docs/guides/speech-to-text#prompting) should match the audio language.

properties.name: response_format
properties.description: The format of the output, in one of these options: `json`, `text`, `srt`, `verbose_json`, or `vtt`. For `gpt-4o-transcribe` and `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe`, the only supported format is `json`.

properties.name: temperature
properties.description: The sampling temperature, between 0 and 1. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic. If set to 0, the model will use [log probability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Log_probability) to automatically increase the temperature until certain thresholds are hit.

properties.name: include[]
properties.description:
Additional information to include in the transcription response. 
`logprobs` will return the log probabilities of the tokens in the 
response to understand the model's confidence in the transcription. 
`logprobs` only works with response_format set to `json` and only with 
the models `gpt-4o-transcribe` and `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe`.

properties.name: timestamp_granularities[]
properties.description: The timestamp granularities to populate for this transcription. `response_format` must be set `verbose_json` to use timestamp granularities. Either or both of these options are supported: `word`, or `segment`. Note: There is no additional latency for segment timestamps, but generating word timestamps incurs additional latency.

properties.name: stream
properties.description:
If set to true, the model response data will be streamed to the client
as it is generated using [server-sent events](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Server-sent_events/Using_server-sent_events#Event_stream_format). 
See the [Streaming section of the Speech-to-Text guide](/docs/guides/speech-to-text?lang=curl#streaming-transcriptions)
for more information.

Note: Streaming is not supported for the `whisper-1` model and will be ignored.

definitions.title: Response
definitions.description: The [transcription object](/docs/api-reference/audio/json-object), a [verbose transcription object](/docs/api-reference/audio/verbose-json-object) or a [stream of transcript events](/docs/api-reference/audio/transcript-text-delta-event).

title: Create translation
description:
---
group:
  - Audio
---
Translates audio into English.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/audio/translations \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: multipart/form-data" \
  -F file="@/path/to/file/german.m4a" \
  -F model="whisper-1"

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

audio_file = open("speech.mp3", "rb")
transcript = client.audio.translations.create(
  model="whisper-1",
  file=audio_file
)

tabs.title: javascript
csharp

properties.name: file
properties.description: The audio file object (not file name) translate, in one of these formats: flac, mp3, mp4, mpeg, mpga, m4a, ogg, wav, or webm.

properties.name: model
properties.description: ID of the model to use. Only `whisper-1` (which is powered by our open source Whisper V2 model) is currently available.

properties.name: prompt
properties.description: An optional text to guide the model's style or continue a previous audio segment. The [prompt](/docs/guides/speech-to-text#prompting) should be in English.

properties.name: response_format
properties.description: The format of the output, in one of these options: `json`, `text`, `srt`, `verbose_json`, or `vtt`.

properties.name: temperature
properties.description: The sampling temperature, between 0 and 1. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic. If set to 0, the model will use [log probability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Log_probability) to automatically increase the temperature until certain thresholds are hit.

title: The transcription object (JSON)
description: Represents a transcription response returned by model, based on the provided input.

properties.name: text
properties.description: The transcribed text.

properties.name: logprobs
properties.description: The log probabilities of the tokens in the transcription. Only returned with the models `gpt-4o-transcribe` and `gpt-4o-mini-transcribe` if `logprobs` is added to the `include` array.

properties.name: token
properties.description: The token in the transcription.

properties.name: logprob
properties.description: The log probability of the token.

properties.name: bytes
properties.description: The bytes of the token.

title: The transcription object (Verbose JSON)
description: Represents a verbose json transcription response returned by model, based on the provided input.

properties.name: language
properties.description: The language of the input audio.

properties.name: duration
properties.description: The duration of the input audio.

properties.name: text
properties.description: The transcribed text.

properties.name: words
properties.description: Extracted words and their corresponding timestamps.

properties.name: word
properties.description: The text content of the word.

properties.name: start
properties.description: Start time of the word in seconds.

properties.name: end
properties.description: End time of the word in seconds.

properties.name: segments
properties.description: Segments of the transcribed text and their corresponding details.

properties.name: id
properties.description: Unique identifier of the segment.

properties.name: seek
properties.description: Seek offset of the segment.

properties.name: start
properties.description: Start time of the segment in seconds.

properties.name: end
properties.description: End time of the segment in seconds.

properties.name: text
properties.description: Text content of the segment.

properties.name: tokens
properties.description: Array of token IDs for the text content.

properties.name: temperature
properties.description: Temperature parameter used for generating the segment.

properties.name: avg_logprob
properties.description: Average logprob of the segment. If the value is lower than -1, consider the logprobs failed.

properties.name: compression_ratio
properties.description: Compression ratio of the segment. If the value is greater than 2.4, consider the compression failed.

properties.name: no_speech_prob
properties.description: Probability of no speech in the segment. If the value is higher than 1.0 and the `avg_logprob` is below -1, consider this segment silent.

title: Stream Event (transcript.text.delta)
description: Emitted when there is an additional text delta. This is also the first event emitted when the transcription starts. Only emitted when you [create a transcription](/docs/api-reference/audio/create-transcription) with the `Stream` parameter set to `true`.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The type of the event. Always `transcript.text.delta`.

properties.name: delta
properties.description: The text delta that was additionally transcribed.

properties.name: logprobs
properties.description: The log probabilities of the delta. Only included if you [create a transcription](/docs/api-reference/audio/create-transcription) with the `include[]` parameter set to `logprobs`.

properties.name: token
properties.description: The token that was used to generate the log probability.

properties.name: logprob
properties.description: The log probability of the token.

properties.name: bytes
properties.description: The bytes that were used to generate the log probability.

title: Stream Event (transcript.text.done)
description: Emitted when the transcription is complete. Contains the complete transcription text. Only emitted when you [create a transcription](/docs/api-reference/audio/create-transcription) with the `Stream` parameter set to `true`.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The type of the event. Always `transcript.text.done`.

properties.name: text
properties.description: The text that was transcribed.

properties.name: logprobs
properties.description: The log probabilities of the individual tokens in the transcription. Only included if you [create a transcription](/docs/api-reference/audio/create-transcription) with the `include[]` parameter set to `logprobs`.

properties.name: token
properties.description: The token that was used to generate the log probability.

properties.name: logprob
properties.description: The log probability of the token.

properties.name: bytes
properties.description: The bytes that were used to generate the log probability.

title: Create image
description:
---
group:
  - Images
---
Creates an image given a prompt. [Learn more](/docs/guides/images).

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/images/generations \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -d '{
    "model": "gpt-image-1",
    "prompt": "A cute baby sea otter",
    "n": 1,
    "size": "1024x1024"
  }'

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
import base64
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

img = client.images.generate(
    model="gpt-image-1",
    prompt="A cute baby sea otter",
    n=1,
    size="1024x1024"
)

image_bytes = base64.b64decode(img.data[0].b64_json)
with open("output.png", "wb") as f:
    f.write(image_bytes)

tabs.title: js

properties.name: prompt
properties.description: A text description of the desired image(s). The maximum length is 32000 characters for `gpt-image-1`, 1000 characters for `dall-e-2` and 4000 characters for `dall-e-3`.

properties.name: model
properties.description: The model to use for image generation. One of `dall-e-2`, `dall-e-3`, or `gpt-image-1`. Defaults to `dall-e-2` unless a parameter specific to `gpt-image-1` is used.

properties.name: n
properties.description: The number of images to generate. Must be between 1 and 10. For `dall-e-3`, only `n=1` is supported.

properties.name: quality
properties.description:
The quality of the image that will be generated. 

- `auto` (default value) will automatically select the best quality for the given model.
- `high`, `medium` and `low` are supported for `gpt-image-1`.
- `hd` and `standard` are supported for `dall-e-3`.
- `standard` is the only option for `dall-e-2`.

properties.name: response_format
properties.description: The format in which generated images with `dall-e-2` and `dall-e-3` are returned. Must be one of `url` or `b64_json`. URLs are only valid for 60 minutes after the image has been generated. This parameter isn't supported for `gpt-image-1` which will always return base64-encoded images.

properties.name: output_format
properties.description: The format in which the generated images are returned. This parameter is only supported for `gpt-image-1`. Must be one of `png`, `jpeg`, or `webp`.

properties.name: output_compression
properties.description: The compression level (0-100%) for the generated images. This parameter is only supported for `gpt-image-1` with the `webp` or `jpeg` output formats, and defaults to 100.

properties.name: size
properties.description: The size of the generated images. Must be one of `1024x1024`, `1536x1024` (landscape), `1024x1536` (portrait), or `auto` (default value) for `gpt-image-1`, one of `256x256`, `512x512`, or `1024x1024` for `dall-e-2`, and one of `1024x1024`, `1792x1024`, or `1024x1792` for `dall-e-3`.

properties.name: moderation
properties.description: Control the content-moderation level for images generated by `gpt-image-1`. Must be either `low` for less restrictive filtering or `auto` (default value).

properties.name: background
properties.description:
Allows to set transparency for the background of the generated image(s). 
This parameter is only supported for `gpt-image-1`. Must be one of 
`transparent`, `opaque` or `auto` (default value). When `auto` is used, the 
model will automatically determine the best background for the image.

If `transparent`, the output format needs to support transparency, so it 
should be set to either `png` (default value) or `webp`.

properties.name: style
properties.description: The style of the generated images. This parameter is only supported for `dall-e-3`. Must be one of `vivid` or `natural`. Vivid causes the model to lean towards generating hyper-real and dramatic images. Natural causes the model to produce more natural, less hyper-real looking images.

properties.name: user
properties.description: A unique identifier representing your end-user, which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse. [Learn more](/docs/guides/safety-best-practices#end-user-ids).

title: Create image edit
description:
---
group:
  - Images
---
Creates an edited or extended image given one or more source images and a prompt. This endpoint only supports `gpt-image-1` and `dall-e-2`.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl -s -D >(grep -i x-request-id >&2) \
  -o >(jq -r '.data[0].b64_json' | base64 --decode > gift-basket.png) \
  -X POST "https://api.openai.com/v1/images/edits" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -F "model=gpt-image-1" \
  -F "image[]=@body-lotion.png" \
  -F "image[]=@bath-bomb.png" \
  -F "image[]=@incense-kit.png" \
  -F "image[]=@soap.png" \
  -F 'prompt=Create a lovely gift basket with these four items in it'

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
import base64
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

prompt = """
Generate a photorealistic image of a gift basket on a white background 
labeled 'Relax & Unwind' with a ribbon and handwriting-like font, 
containing all the items in the reference pictures.
"""

result = client.images.edit(
    model="gpt-image-1",
    image=[
        open("body-lotion.png", "rb"),
        open("bath-bomb.png", "rb"),
        open("incense-kit.png", "rb"),
        open("soap.png", "rb"),
    ],
    prompt=prompt
)

image_base64 = result.data[0].b64_json
image_bytes = base64.b64decode(image_base64)

# Save the image to a file
with open("gift-basket.png", "wb") as f:
    f.write(image_bytes)

tabs.title: js

properties.name: image
properties.description:
The image(s) to edit. Must be a supported image file or an array of images.

For `gpt-image-1`, each image should be a `png`, `webp`, or `jpg` file less 
than 25MB. You can provide up to 16 images.

For `dall-e-2`, you can only provide one image, and it should be a square 
`png` file less than 4MB.

properties.name: prompt
properties.description: A text description of the desired image(s). The maximum length is 1000 characters for `dall-e-2`, and 32000 characters for `gpt-image-1`.

properties.name: mask
properties.description: An additional image whose fully transparent areas (e.g. where alpha is zero) indicate where `image` should be edited. If there are multiple images provided, the mask will be applied on the first image. Must be a valid PNG file, less than 4MB, and have the same dimensions as `image`.

properties.name: model
properties.description: The model to use for image generation. Only `dall-e-2` and `gpt-image-1` are supported. Defaults to `dall-e-2` unless a parameter specific to `gpt-image-1` is used.

properties.name: n
properties.description: The number of images to generate. Must be between 1 and 10.

properties.name: size
properties.description: The size of the generated images. Must be one of `1024x1024`, `1536x1024` (landscape), `1024x1536` (portrait), or `auto` (default value) for `gpt-image-1`, and one of `256x256`, `512x512`, or `1024x1024` for `dall-e-2`.

properties.name: response_format
properties.description: The format in which the generated images are returned. Must be one of `url` or `b64_json`. URLs are only valid for 60 minutes after the image has been generated. This parameter is only supported for `dall-e-2`, as `gpt-image-1` will always return base64-encoded images.

properties.name: user
properties.description: A unique identifier representing your end-user, which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse. [Learn more](/docs/guides/safety-best-practices#end-user-ids).

properties.name: quality
properties.description: The quality of the image that will be generated. `high`, `medium` and `low` are only supported for `gpt-image-1`. `dall-e-2` only supports `standard` quality. Defaults to `auto`.

title: Create image variation
description:
---
group:
  - Images
---
Creates a variation of a given image. This endpoint only supports `dall-e-2`.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/images/variations \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -F image="@otter.png" \
  -F n=2 \
  -F size="1024x1024"

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

response = client.images.create_variation(
  image=open("image_edit_original.png", "rb"),
  n=2,
  size="1024x1024"
)

tabs.title: js
csharp

properties.name: image
properties.description: The image to use as the basis for the variation(s). Must be a valid PNG file, less than 4MB, and square.

properties.name: model
properties.description: The model to use for image generation. Only `dall-e-2` is supported at this time.

properties.name: n
properties.description: The number of images to generate. Must be between 1 and 10.

properties.name: response_format
properties.description: The format in which the generated images are returned. Must be one of `url` or `b64_json`. URLs are only valid for 60 minutes after the image has been generated.

properties.name: size
properties.description: The size of the generated images. Must be one of `256x256`, `512x512`, or `1024x1024`.

properties.name: user
properties.description: A unique identifier representing your end-user, which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse. [Learn more](/docs/guides/safety-best-practices#end-user-ids).

title: The image generation response
description: The response from the image generation endpoint.

properties.name: created
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) of when the image was created.

properties.name: data
properties.description: The list of generated images.

properties.name: items
properties.description: Represents the content or the URL of an image generated by the OpenAI API.

properties.name: b64_json
properties.description: The base64-encoded JSON of the generated image. Default value for `gpt-image-1`, and only present if `response_format` is set to `b64_json` for `dall-e-2` and `dall-e-3`.

properties.name: url
properties.description: When using `dall-e-2` or `dall-e-3`, the URL of the generated image if `response_format` is set to `url` (default value). Unsupported for `gpt-image-1`.

properties.name: revised_prompt
properties.description: For `dall-e-3` only, the revised prompt that was used to generate the image.

properties.name: usage
properties.description: For `gpt-image-1` only, the token usage information for the image generation.

properties.name: total_tokens
properties.description: The total number of tokens (images and text) used for the image generation.

properties.name: input_tokens
properties.description: The number of tokens (images and text) in the input prompt.

properties.name: output_tokens
properties.description: The number of image tokens in the output image.

properties.name: input_tokens_details
properties.description: The input tokens detailed information for the image generation.

properties.name: text_tokens
properties.description: The number of text tokens in the input prompt.

properties.name: image_tokens
properties.description: The number of image tokens in the input prompt.

title: Create embeddings
description:
---
group:
  - Embeddings
---
Creates an embedding vector representing the input text.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/embeddings \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "input": "The food was delicious and the waiter...",
    "model": "text-embedding-ada-002",
    "encoding_format": "float"
  }'

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

client.embeddings.create(
  model="text-embedding-ada-002",
  input="The food was delicious and the waiter...",
  encoding_format="float"
)

tabs.title: js
csharp

properties.name: input
properties.description: Input text to embed, encoded as a string or array of tokens. To embed multiple inputs in a single request, pass an array of strings or array of token arrays. The input must not exceed the max input tokens for the model (8192 tokens for `text-embedding-ada-002`), cannot be an empty string, and any array must be 2048 dimensions or less. [Example Python code](https://cookbook.openai.com/examples/how_to_count_tokens_with_tiktoken) for counting tokens. Some models may also impose a limit on total number of tokens summed across inputs.

properties.name: model
properties.description: ID of the model to use. You can use the [List models](/docs/api-reference/models/list) API to see all of your available models, or see our [Model overview](/docs/models) for descriptions of them.

properties.name: encoding_format
properties.description: The format to return the embeddings in. Can be either `float` or [`base64`](https://pypi.org/project/pybase64/).

properties.name: dimensions
properties.description: The number of dimensions the resulting output embeddings should have. Only supported in `text-embedding-3` and later models.

properties.name: user
properties.description: A unique identifier representing your end-user, which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse. [Learn more](/docs/guides/safety-best-practices#end-user-ids).

title: The embedding object
description: Represents an embedding vector returned by embedding endpoint.

properties.name: index
properties.description: The index of the embedding in the list of embeddings.

properties.name: embedding
properties.description: The embedding vector, which is a list of floats. The length of vector depends on the model as listed in the [embedding guide](/docs/guides/embeddings).

properties.name: object
properties.description: The object type, which is always "embedding".

title: Create eval
description:
---
group:
  - Evals
---
Create the structure of an evaluation that can be used to test a model's performance.
An evaluation is a set of testing criteria and a datasource. After creating an evaluation, you can run it on different models and model parameters. We support several types of graders and datasources.
For more information, see the [Evals guide](/docs/guides/evals).

tabs.title: bash

properties.name: name
properties.description: The name of the evaluation.

properties.name: metadata
properties.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. 

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

properties.name: data_source_config
properties.description: The configuration for the data source used for the evaluation runs.

properties.name: testing_criteria
properties.description: A list of graders for all eval runs in this group.

title: Create eval run
description:
---
group:
  - Evals
---
Create a new evaluation run. This is the endpoint that will kick off grading.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/evals/eval_67e579652b548190aaa83ada4b125f47/runs \
  -X POST \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"name":"gpt-4o-mini","data_source":{"type":"completions","input_messages":{"type":"template","template":[{"role":"developer","content":"Categorize a given news headline into one of the following topics: Technology, Markets, World, Business, or Sports.

# Steps

1. Analyze the content of the news headline to understand its primary focus.
2. Extract the subject matter, identifying any key indicators or keywords.
3. Use the identified indicators to determine the most suitable category out of the five options: Technology, Markets, World, Business, or Sports.
4. Ensure only one category is selected per headline.

# Output Format

Respond with the chosen category as a single word. For instance: "Technology", "Markets", "World", "Business", or "Sports".

# Examples

**Input**: "Apple Unveils New iPhone Model, Featuring Advanced AI Features"  
**Output**: "Technology"

**Input**: "Global Stocks Mixed as Investors Await Central Bank Decisions"  
**Output**: "Markets"

**Input**: "War in Ukraine: Latest Updates on Negotiation Status"  
**Output**: "World"

**Input**: "Microsoft in Talks to Acquire Gaming Company for $2 Billion"  
**Output**: "Business"

**Input**: "Manchester United Secures Win in Premier League Football Match"  
**Output**: "Sports" 

# Notes

- If the headline appears to fit into more than one category, choose the most dominant theme.
- Keywords or phrases such as "stocks", "company acquisition", "match", or technological brands can be good indicators for classification.
"} , {"role":"user","content":"{{item.input}}"}]},"sampling_params":{"temperature":1,"max_completions_tokens":2048,"top_p":1,"seed":42},"model":"gpt-4o-mini","source":{"type":"file_content","content":[{"item":{"input":"Tech Company Launches Advanced Artificial Intelligence Platform","ground_truth":"Technology"}}]}}'

properties.name: eval_id
properties.description: The ID of the evaluation to create a run for.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The name of the run.

properties.name: metadata
properties.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. 

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

properties.name: data_source
properties.description: Details about the run's data source.

definitions.title: Response
definitions.description: The [EvalRun](/docs/api-reference/evals/run-object) object matching the specified ID.

title: The eval object
description:
An Eval object with a data source config and testing criteria.
An Eval represents a task to be done for your LLM integration.
Like:
 - Improve the quality of my chatbot
 - See how well my chatbot handles customer support
 - Check if o3-mini is better at my usecase than gpt-4o

with a maximum length of 512 characters.

title: Create fine-tuning job
description:
---
group:
  - Fine-tuning
---
Creates a fine-tuning job which begins the process of creating a new model from a given dataset.

Response includes details of the enqueued job including job status and the name of the fine-tuned models once complete.

[Learn more about fine-tuning](/docs/guides/fine-tuning)

tabs.title: curl
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/fine_tuning/jobs \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -d '{
    "training_file": "file-BK7bzQj3FfZFXr7DbL6xJwfo",
    "model": "gpt-4o-mini"
  }'

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

client.fine_tuning.jobs.create(
  training_file="file-abc123",
  model="gpt-4o-mini"
)

tabs.title: node.js
curl
python
node.js
curl
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/fine_tuning/jobs \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -d '{
    "training_file": "file-abc123",
    "validation_file": "file-abc123",
    "model": "gpt-4o-mini"
  }'

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

client.fine_tuning.jobs.create(
  training_file="file-abc123",
  validation_file="file-def456",
  model="gpt-4o-mini"
)

tabs.title: node.js
curl
curl

properties.name: model
properties.description:
The name of the model to fine-tune. You can select one of the
[supported models](/docs/guides/fine-tuning#which-models-can-be-fine-tuned).

properties.name: training_file
properties.description:
The ID of an uploaded file that contains training data.

See [upload file](/docs/api-reference/files/create) for how to upload a file.

Your dataset must be formatted as a JSONL file. Additionally, you must upload your file with the purpose `fine-tune`.

The contents of the file should differ depending on if the model uses the [chat](/docs/api-reference/fine-tuning/chat-input), [completions](/docs/api-reference/fine-tuning/completions-input) format, or if the fine-tuning method uses the [preference](/docs/api-reference/fine-tuning/preference-input) format.

See the [fine-tuning guide](/docs/guides/fine-tuning) for more details.

properties.name: hyperparameters
properties.description:
The hyperparameters used for the fine-tuning job.
This value is now deprecated in favor of `method`, and should be passed in under the `method` parameter.

properties.name: batch_size
properties.description:
Number of examples in each batch. A larger batch size means that model parameters
are updated less frequently, but with lower variance.

properties.name: learning_rate_multiplier
properties.description:
Scaling factor for the learning rate. A smaller learning rate may be useful to avoid
overfitting.

properties.name: n_epochs
properties.description:
The number of epochs to train the model for. An epoch refers to one full cycle
through the training dataset.

properties.name: suffix
properties.description:
A string of up to 64 characters that will be added to your fine-tuned model name.

For example, a `suffix` of "custom-model-name" would produce a model name like `ft:gpt-4o-mini:openai:custom-model-name:7p4lURel`.

properties.name: validation_file
properties.description:
The ID of an uploaded file that contains validation data.

If you provide this file, the data is used to generate validation
metrics periodically during fine-tuning. These metrics can be viewed in
the fine-tuning results file.
The same data should not be present in both train and validation files.

Your dataset must be formatted as a JSONL file. You must upload your file with the purpose `fine-tune`.

See the [fine-tuning guide](/docs/guides/fine-tuning) for more details.

properties.name: integrations
properties.description: A list of integrations to enable for your fine-tuning job.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The type of integration to enable. Currently, only "wandb" (Weights and Biases) is supported.

properties.name: wandb
properties.description:
The settings for your integration with Weights and Biases. This payload specifies the project that
metrics will be sent to. Optionally, you can set an explicit display name for your run, add tags
to your run, and set a default entity (team, username, etc) to be associated with your run.

properties.name: project
properties.description: The name of the project that the new run will be created under.

properties.name: name
properties.description: A display name to set for the run. If not set, we will use the Job ID as the name.

properties.name: entity
properties.description:
The entity to use for the run. This allows you to set the team or username of the WandB user that you would
like associated with the run. If not set, the default entity for the registered WandB API key is used.

properties.name: tags
properties.description:
A list of tags to be attached to the newly created run. These tags are passed through directly to WandB. Some
default tags are generated by OpenAI: "openai/finetune", "openai/{base-model}", "openai/{ftjob-abcdef}".

properties.name: seed
properties.description:
The seed controls the reproducibility of the job. Passing in the same seed and job parameters should produce the same results, but may differ in rare cases.
If a seed is not specified, one will be generated for you.

properties.name: method
properties.description: The method used for fine-tuning.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The type of method. Is either `supervised` or `dpo`.

properties.name: supervised
properties.description: Configuration for the supervised fine-tuning method.

properties.name: hyperparameters
properties.description: The hyperparameters used for the fine-tuning job.

properties.name: batch_size
properties.description: Number of examples in each batch. A larger batch size means that model parameters are updated less frequently, but with lower variance.

properties.name: learning_rate_multiplier
properties.description: Scaling factor for the learning rate. A smaller learning rate may be useful to avoid overfitting.

properties.name: n_epochs
properties.description: The number of epochs to train the model for. An epoch refers to one full cycle through the training dataset.

properties.name: dpo
properties.description: Configuration for the DPO fine-tuning method.

properties.name: hyperparameters
properties.description: The hyperparameters used for the fine-tuning job.

properties.name: beta
properties.description: The beta value for the DPO method. A higher beta value will increase the weight of the penalty between the policy and reference model.

properties.name: batch_size
properties.description: Number of examples in each batch. A larger batch size means that model parameters are updated less frequently, but with lower variance.

properties.name: learning_rate_multiplier
properties.description: Scaling factor for the learning rate. A smaller learning rate may be useful to avoid overfitting.

properties.name: n_epochs
properties.description: The number of epochs to train the model for. An epoch refers to one full cycle through the training dataset.

properties.name: metadata
properties.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. 

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

properties.name: tools
properties.description: A list of tools the model may generate JSON inputs for.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The type of the tool. Currently, only `function` is supported.

properties.name: description
properties.description: A description of what the function does, used by the model to choose when and how to call the function.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The name of the function to be called. Must be a-z, A-Z, 0-9, or contain underscores and dashes, with a maximum length of 64.

properties.name: parameters
properties.description:
The parameters the functions accepts, described as a JSON Schema object. See the [guide](/docs/guides/function-calling) for examples, and the [JSON Schema reference](https://json-schema.org/understanding-json-schema/) for documentation about the format. 

Omitting `parameters` defines a function with an empty parameter list.

properties.name: strict
properties.description: Whether to enable strict schema adherence when generating the function call. If set to true, the model will follow the exact schema defined in the `parameters` field. Only a subset of JSON Schema is supported when `strict` is `true`. Learn more about Structured Outputs in the [function calling guide](docs/guides/function-calling).

properties.name: parallel_tool_calls
properties.description: Whether to enable [parallel function calling](/docs/guides/function-calling#configuring-parallel-function-calling) during tool use.

properties.name: functions

properties.name: name

properties.name: parameters

properties.name: parameters
properties.description:
The parameters the functions accepts, described as a JSON Schema object. See the [guide](/docs/guides/function-calling) for examples, and the [JSON Schema reference](https://json-schema.org/understanding-json-schema/) for documentation about the format. 

Omitting `parameters` defines a function with an empty parameter list.

properties.name: strict
properties.description: Whether to enable strict schema adherence when generating the function call. If set to true, the model will follow the exact schema defined in the `parameters` field. Only a subset of JSON Schema is supported when `strict` is `true`. Learn more about Structured Outputs in the [function calling guide](docs/guides/function-calling).

properties.name: parallel_tool_calls
properties.description: Whether to enable [parallel function calling](/docs/guides/function-calling#configuring-parallel-function-calling) during tool use.

properties.name: preferred_completion
properties.description: The preferred completion message for the output.

properties.name: non_preferred_completion
properties.description: The non-preferred completion message for the output.

title: Training format for completions models
description: The per-line training example of a fine-tuning input file for completions models

properties.name: prompt
properties.description: The input prompt for this training example.

properties.name: completion
properties.description: The desired completion for this training example.

title: The fine-tuning job object
description: The `fine_tuning.job` object represents a fine-tuning job that has been created through the API.

properties.name: id
properties.description: The object identifier, which can be referenced in the API endpoints.

properties.name: created_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the fine-tuning job was created.

properties.name: error
properties.description: For fine-tuning jobs that have `failed`, this will contain more information on the cause of the failure.

properties.name: code
properties.description: A machine-readable error code.

properties.name: message
properties.description: A human-readable error message.

properties.name: param
properties.description: The parameter that was invalid, usually `training_file` or `validation_file`. This field will be null if the failure was not parameter-specific.

properties.name: fine_tuned_model
properties.description: The name of the fine-tuned model that is being created. The value will be null if the fine-tuning job is still running.

properties.name: finished_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the fine-tuning job was finished. The value will be null if the fine-tuning job is still running.

properties.name: hyperparameters
properties.description: The hyperparameters used for the fine-tuning job. This value will only be returned when running `supervised` jobs.

properties.name: batch_size
properties.description:
Number of examples in each batch. A larger batch size means that model parameters
are updated less frequently, but with lower variance.

properties.name: learning_rate_multiplier
properties.description:
Scaling factor for the learning rate. A smaller learning rate may be useful to avoid
overfitting.

properties.name: n_epochs
properties.description:
The number of epochs to train the model for. An epoch refers to one full cycle
through the training dataset.

properties.name: model
properties.description: The base model that is being fine-tuned.

properties.name: object
properties.description: The object type, which is always "fine_tuning.job".

properties.name: organization_id
properties.description: The organization that owns the fine-tuning job.

properties.name: result_files
properties.description: The compiled results file ID(s) for the fine-tuning job. You can retrieve the results with the [Files API](/docs/api-reference/files/retrieve-contents).

properties.name: status
properties.description: The current status of the fine-tuning job, which can be either `validating_files`, `queued`, `running`, `succeeded`, `failed`, or `cancelled`.

properties.name: trained_tokens
properties.description: The total number of billable tokens processed by this fine-tuning job. The value will be null if the fine-tuning job is still running.

properties.name: training_file
properties.description: The file ID used for training. You can retrieve the training data with the [Files API](/docs/api-reference/files/retrieve-contents).

properties.name: validation_file
properties.description: The file ID used for validation. You can retrieve the validation results with the [Files API](/docs/api-reference/files/retrieve-contents).

properties.name: integrations
properties.description: A list of integrations to enable for this fine-tuning job.

properties.name: seed
properties.description: The seed used for the fine-tuning job.

properties.name: estimated_finish
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the fine-tuning job is estimated to finish. The value will be null if the fine-tuning job is not running.

properties.name: method
properties.description: The method used for fine-tuning.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The type of method. Is either `supervised` or `dpo`.

properties.name: supervised
properties.description: Configuration for the supervised fine-tuning method.

properties.name: hyperparameters
properties.description: The hyperparameters used for the fine-tuning job.

properties.name: batch_size
properties.description: Number of examples in each batch. A larger batch size means that model parameters are updated less frequently, but with lower variance.

properties.name: learning_rate_multiplier
properties.description: Scaling factor for the learning rate. A smaller learning rate may be useful to avoid overfitting.

properties.name: n_epochs
properties.description: The number of epochs to train the model for. An epoch refers to one full cycle through the training dataset.

properties.name: dpo
properties.description: Configuration for the DPO fine-tuning method.

properties.name: hyperparameters
properties.description: The hyperparameters used for the fine-tuning job.

properties.name: beta
properties.description: The beta value for the DPO method. A higher beta value will increase the weight of the penalty between the policy and reference model.

properties.name: batch_size
properties.description: Number of examples in each batch. A larger batch size means that model parameters are updated less frequently, but with lower variance.

properties.name: learning_rate_multiplier
properties.description: Scaling factor for the learning rate. A smaller learning rate may be useful to avoid overfitting.

properties.name: n_epochs
properties.description: The number of epochs to train the model for. An epoch refers to one full cycle through the training dataset.

properties.name: metadata
properties.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. 

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

title: Create batch
description:
---
group:
  - Batch
---
Creates and executes a batch from an uploaded file of requests

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/batches \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "input_file_id": "file-abc123",
    "endpoint": "/v1/chat/completions",
    "completion_window": "24h"
  }'

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

client.batches.create(
  input_file_id="file-abc123",
  endpoint="/v1/chat/completions",
  completion_window="24h"
)

tabs.title: node

tabs.code:
{
  "id": "batch_abc123",
  "object": "batch",
  "endpoint": "/v1/chat/completions",
  "errors": null,
  "input_file_id": "file-abc123",
  "completion_window": "24h",
  "status": "validating",
  "output_file_id": null,
  "error_file_id": null,
  "created_at": 1711471533,
  "in_progress_at": null,
  "expires_at": null,
  "finalizing_at": null,
  "completed_at": null,
  "failed_at": null,
  "expired_at": null,
  "cancelling_at": null,
  "cancelled_at": null,
  "request_counts": {
    "total": 0,
    "completed": 0,
    "failed": 0
  },
  "metadata": {
    "customer_id": "user_123456789",
    "batch_description": "Nightly eval job",
  }
}

properties.name: input_file_id
properties.description:
The ID of an uploaded file that contains requests for the new batch.

See [upload file](/docs/api-reference/files/create) for how to upload a file.

Your input file must be formatted as a [JSONL file](/docs/api-reference/batch/request-input), and must be uploaded with the purpose `batch`. The file can contain up to 50,000 requests, and can be up to 200 MB in size.

properties.name: endpoint
properties.description: The endpoint to be used for all requests in the batch. Currently `/v1/responses`, `/v1/chat/completions`, `/v1/embeddings`, and `/v1/completions` are supported. Note that `/v1/embeddings` batches are also restricted to a maximum of 50,000 embedding inputs across all requests in the batch.

properties.name: completion_window
properties.description: The time frame within which the batch should be processed. Currently only `24h` is supported.

properties.name: metadata
properties.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. 

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

title: Cancel batch
description:
---
group:
  - Batch
---
Cancels an in-progress batch. The batch will be in status `cancelling` for up to 10 minutes, before changing to `cancelled`, where it will have partial results (if any) available in the output file.

curl https://api.openai.com/v1/batches/batch_abc123/cancel \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -X POST

title: Upload file
description:
---
group:
  - Files
---
Upload a file that can be used across various endpoints. Individual files can be up to 512 MB, and the size of all files uploaded by one organization can be up to 100 GB.

The Assistants API supports files up to 2 million tokens and of specific file types. See the [Assistants Tools guide](/docs/assistants/tools) for details.

The Fine-tuning API only supports `.jsonl` files. The input also has certain required formats for fine-tuning [chat](/docs/api-reference/fine-tuning/chat-input) or [completions](/docs/api-reference/fine-tuning/completions-input) models.

The Batch API only supports `.jsonl` files up to 200 MB in size. The input also has a specific required [format](/docs/api-reference/batch/request-input).

Please [contact us](https://help.openai.com/) if you need to increase these storage limits.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/files \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -F purpose="fine-tune" \
  -F file="@mydata.jsonl"

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

client.files.create(
  file=open("mydata.jsonl", "rb"),
  purpose="fine-tune"
)

tabs.title: js

tabs.code:
{
  "id": "file-abc123",
  "object": "file",
  "bytes": 120000,
  "created_at": 1677610602,
  "filename": "mydata.jsonl",
  "purpose": "fine-tune",
}

properties.name: file
properties.description: The File object (not file name) to be uploaded.

properties.name: purpose
properties.description: The intended purpose of the uploaded file. One of: - `assistants`: Used in the Assistants API - `batch`: Used in the Batch API - `fine-tune`: Used for fine-tuning - `vision`: Images used for vision fine-tuning - `user_data`: Flexible file type for any purpose - `evals`: Used for eval data sets

title: The file object
description: The `File` object represents a document that has been uploaded to OpenAI.

properties.name: id
properties.description: The file identifier, which can be referenced in the API endpoints.

properties.name: purpose

properties.name: status
properties.description: Deprecated. The current status of the file, which can be either `uploaded`, `processed`, or `error`.

properties.name: status_details
properties.description: Deprecated. For details on why a fine-tuning training file failed validation, see the `error` field on `fine_tuning.job`.

title: Create upload
description:
---
group:
  - Uploads
---
Creates an intermediate [Upload](/docs/api-reference/uploads/object) object
that you can add [Parts](/docs/api-reference/uploads/part-object) to.
Currently, an Upload can accept at most 8 GB in total and expires after an
hour after you create it.

Once you complete the Upload, we will create a
[File](/docs/api-reference/files/object) object that contains all the parts
you uploaded. This File is usable in the rest of our platform as a regular
File object.

For certain `purpose` values, the correct `mime_type` must be specified. 
Please refer to documentation for the 
[supported MIME types for your use case](/docs/assistants/tools/file-search#supported-files).

For guidance on the proper filename extensions for each purpose, please
follow the documentation on [creating a
File](/docs/api-reference/files/create).

The intended purpose of the uploaded file.

The MIME type of the file.

This must fall within the supported MIME types for your file purpose. See the supported MIME types for assistants and vision.

title: Add upload part
description:
---
group:
  - Uploads
---
Adds a [Part](/docs/api-reference/uploads/part-object) to an [Upload](/docs/api-reference/uploads/object) object. A Part represents a chunk of bytes from the file you are trying to upload. 

Each Part can be at most 64 MB, and you can add Parts until you hit the Upload maximum of 8 GB.

It is possible to add multiple Parts in parallel. You can decide the intended order of the Parts when you [complete the Upload](/docs/api-reference/uploads/complete).

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/uploads/upload_abc123/parts
  -F data="aHR0cHM6Ly9hcGkub3BlbmFpLmNvbS92MS91cGxvYWRz..."

properties.name: upload_id
properties.description: The ID of the Upload.

properties.name: data
properties.description: The chunk of bytes for this Part.

title: Complete upload
description:
---
group:
  - Uploads
---
Completes the [Upload](/docs/api-reference/uploads/object). 

Within the returned Upload object, there is a nested [File](/docs/api-reference/files/object) object that is ready to use in the rest of the platform.

You can specify the order of the Parts by passing in an ordered list of the Part IDs.

The number of bytes uploaded upon completion must match the number of bytes initially specified when creating the Upload object. No Parts may be added after an Upload is completed.

tabs.title: bash

tabs.code:
{
  "id": "upload_abc123",
  "object": "upload",
  "bytes": 2147483648,
  "created_at": 1719184911,
  "filename": "training_examples.jsonl",
  "purpose": "fine-tune",
  "status": "completed",
  "expires_at": 1719127296,
  "file": {
    "id": "file-xyz321",
    "object": "file",
    "bytes": 2147483648,
    "created_at": 1719186911,
    "filename": "training_examples.jsonl",
    "purpose": "fine-tune",
  }
}

properties.name: upload_id
properties.description: The ID of the Upload.

properties.name: part_ids
properties.description: The ordered list of Part IDs.

properties.name: md5
properties.description: The optional md5 checksum for the file contents to verify if the bytes uploaded matches what you expect.

definitions.title: Response
definitions.description: The [Upload](/docs/api-reference/uploads/object) object with status `completed` with an additional `file` property containing the created usable File object.

title: Cancel upload

group:

  "filename": "training_examples.jsonl",

  "status": "cancelled",
  "expires_at": 1719127296
}

properties.name: input
properties.description:
Input (or inputs) to classify. Can be a single string, an array of strings, or
an array of multi-modal input objects similar to other models.

properties.name: model

The content moderation model you would like to use. Learn more in
[the moderation guide](/docs/guides/moderation), and learn about

title: The moderation object
description: Represents if a given text input is potentially harmful.

properties.name: id
properties.description: The unique identifier for the moderation request.

properties.name: model
properties.description: The model used to generate the moderation results.

properties.name: results
properties.description: A list of moderation objects.

properties.name: flagged
properties.description: Whether any of the below categories are flagged.

properties.name: categories
properties.description: A list of the categories, and whether they are flagged or not.

properties.name: hate
properties.description: Content that expresses, incites, or promotes hate based on race, gender, ethnicity, religion, nationality, sexual orientation, disability status, or caste. Hateful content aimed at non-protected groups (e.g., chess players) is harassment.

properties.name: hate/threatening
properties.description: Hateful content that also includes violence or serious harm towards the targeted group based on race, gender, ethnicity, religion, nationality, sexual orientation, disability status, or caste.

properties.name: harassment
properties.description: Content that expresses, incites, or promotes harassing language towards any target.

properties.name: harassment/threatening
properties.description: Harassment content that also includes violence or serious harm towards any target.

properties.name: illicit
properties.description: Content that includes instructions or advice that facilitate the planning or execution of wrongdoing, or that gives advice or instruction on how to commit illicit acts. For example, "how to shoplift" would fit this category.

properties.name: illicit/violent
properties.description: Content that includes instructions or advice that facilitate the planning or execution of wrongdoing that also includes violence, or that gives advice or instruction on the procurement of any weapon.

properties.name: self-harm
properties.description: Content that promotes, encourages, or depicts acts of self-harm, such as suicide, cutting, and eating disorders.

properties.name: self-harm/intent
properties.description: Content where the speaker expresses that they are engaging or intend to engage in acts of self-harm, such as suicide, cutting, and eating disorders.

properties.name: self-harm/instructions
properties.description: Content that encourages performing acts of self-harm, such as suicide, cutting, and eating disorders, or that gives instructions or advice on how to commit such acts.

properties.name: sexual
properties.description: Content meant to arouse sexual excitement, such as the description of sexual activity, or that promotes sexual services (excluding sex education and wellness).

properties.name: sexual/minors
properties.description: Sexual content that includes an individual who is under 18 years old.

properties.name: violence
properties.description: Content that depicts death, violence, or physical injury.

properties.name: violence/graphic
properties.description: Content that depicts death, violence, or physical injury in graphic detail.

properties.name: category_scores
properties.description: A list of the categories along with their scores as predicted by model.

properties.name: hate
properties.description: The score for the category 'hate'.

properties.name: hate/threatening
properties.description: The score for the category 'hate/threatening'.

properties.name: harassment
properties.description: The score for the category 'harassment'.

properties.name: harassment/threatening
properties.description: The score for the category 'harassment/threatening'.

properties.name: illicit
properties.description: The score for the category 'illicit'.

properties.name: illicit/violent
properties.description: The score for the category 'illicit/violent'.

properties.description: The score for the category 'self-harm'.

properties.description: The score for the category 'self-harm/intent'.

properties.description: The score for the category 'self-harm/instructions'.

properties.description: The score for the category 'sexual'.

properties.description: The score for the category 'sexual/minors'.

properties.name: violence
properties.description: The score for the category 'violence'.

properties.name: violence/graphic
properties.description: The score for the category 'violence/graphic'.

properties.name: category_applied_input_types
properties.description: A list of the categories along with the input type(s) that the score applies to.

properties.name: hate

properties.name: hate/threatening
properties.description: The applied input type(s) for the category 'hate/threatening'.

title: Create vector store
description:
---
group:
  - Vector stores
---
Create a vector store.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/vector_stores \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "OpenAI-Beta: assistants=v2" \
  -d '{
    "name": "Support FAQ"
  }'

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

vector_store = client.vector_stores.create(
  name="Support FAQ"
)
print(vector_store)

tabs.title: js

tabs.code:
{
  "id": "vs_abc123",
  "object": "vector_store",
  "created_at": 1699061776,
  "name": "Support FAQ",
  "bytes": 139920,
  "file_counts": {
    "in_progress": 0,
    "completed": 3,
    "failed": 0,
    "cancelled": 0,
    "total": 3
  }
}

properties.name: file_ids
properties.description: A list of [File](/docs/api-reference/files) IDs that the vector store should use. Useful for tools like `file_search` that can access files.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The name of the vector store.

properties.name: expires_after
properties.description: The expiration policy for a vector store.

properties.name: anchor
properties.description: Anchor timestamp after which the expiration policy applies. Supported anchors: `last_active_at`.

properties.name: days
properties.description: The number of days after the anchor time that the vector store will expire.

properties.name: chunking_strategy
properties.description: The chunking strategy used to chunk the file(s). If not set, will use the `auto` strategy. Only applicable if `file_ids` is non-empty.

properties.name: metadata
properties.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. 

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

tabs.title: js

properties.name: limit
properties.description: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100, and the default is 20.

properties.name: order
properties.description: Sort order by the `created_at` timestamp of the objects. `asc` for ascending order and `desc` for descending order.

properties.name: after
properties.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `after` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, ending with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include after=obj_foo in order to fetch the next page of the list.

properties.name: before
properties.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `before` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, starting with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include before=obj_foo in order to fetch the previous page of the list.

title: Search vector store
description:
---
group:
  - Vector stores
---
Search a vector store for relevant chunks based on a query and file attributes filter.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl -X POST \
https://api.openai.com/v1/vector_stores/vs_abc123/search \
-H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{"query": "What is the return policy?", "filters": {...}}'

properties.name: vector_store_id
properties.description: The ID of the vector store to search.

properties.name: query
properties.description: A query string for a search

properties.name: rewrite_query
properties.description: Whether to rewrite the natural language query for vector search.

properties.name: max_num_results
properties.description: The maximum number of results to return. This number should be between 1 and 50 inclusive.

properties.name: filters
properties.description: A filter to apply based on file attributes.

properties.name: ranking_options
properties.description: Ranking options for search.

properties.name: ranker
properties.description: Ranking options for search.

properties.name: score_threshold
properties.description: Ranking options for search.

definitions.title: Response
definitions.description: A page of search results from the vector store.

title: The vector store object
description: A vector store is a collection of processed files can be used by the `file_search` tool.

properties.name: id
properties.description: The identifier, which can be referenced in API endpoints.

properties.name: object
properties.description: The object type, which is always `vector_store`.

properties.name: created_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the vector store was created.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The name of the vector store.

properties.name: usage_bytes
properties.description: The total number of bytes used by the files in the vector store.

properties.name: in_progress
properties.description: The number of files that are currently being processed.

properties.name: completed
properties.description: The number of files that have been successfully processed.

properties.name: failed
properties.description: The number of files that have failed to process.

properties.name: cancelled
properties.description: The number of files that were cancelled.

properties.name: total
properties.description: The total number of files.
