title: Create assistant
description:
---
group:
  - Assistants
---
Create an assistant with a model and instructions.

tabs.title: curl
tabs.code:
curl "https://api.openai.com/v1/assistants" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "OpenAI-Beta: assistants=v2" \
  -d '{
    "instructions": "You are a personal math tutor. When asked a question, write and run Python code to answer the question.",
    "name": "Math Tutor",
    "tools": [{"type": "code_interpreter"}],
    "model": "gpt-4o"
  }'

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

my_assistant = client.beta.assistants.create(
    instructions="You are a personal math tutor. When asked a question, write and run Python code to answer the question.",
    name="Math Tutor",
    tools=[{"type": "code_interpreter"}],
    model="gpt-4o",
)
print(my_assistant)

tabs.title: node.js
curl
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/assistants \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "OpenAI-Beta: assistants=v2" \
  -d '{
    "instructions": "You are an HR bot, and you have access to files to answer employee questions about company policies.",
    "tools": [{"type": "file_search"}],
    "tool_resources": {"file_search": {"vector_store_ids": ["vs_123"]}},
    "model": "gpt-4o"
  }'

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

my_assistant = client.beta.assistants.create(
    instructions="You are an HR bot, and you have access to files to answer employee questions about company policies.",
    name="HR Helper",
    tools=[{"type": "file_search"}],
    tool_resources={"file_search": {"vector_store_ids": ["vs_123"]}},
    model="gpt-4o"
)
print(my_assistant)

{
  "id": "asst_abc123",
  "object": "assistant",

  "name": "Math Tutor",

    {
      "type": "code_interpreter"
    }
  ],
  "metadata": {},
  "top_p": 1.0,
  "temperature": 1.0,

}

properties.name: model
properties.description: ID of the model to use. You can use the [List models](/docs/api-reference/models/list) API to see all of your available models, or see our [Model overview](/docs/models) for descriptions of them.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The name of the assistant. The maximum length is 256 characters.

properties.name: description
properties.description: The description of the assistant. The maximum length is 512 characters.

properties.name: instructions
properties.description: The system instructions that the assistant uses. The maximum length is 256,000 characters.

properties.name: reasoning_effort
properties.description:
**o-series models only** 

Constrains effort on reasoning for 
[reasoning models](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/reasoning).
Currently supported values are `low`, `medium`, and `high`. Reducing
reasoning effort can result in faster responses and fewer tokens used
on reasoning in a response.

properties.name: tools
properties.description: A list of tool enabled on the assistant. There can be a maximum of 128 tools per assistant. Tools can be of types `code_interpreter`, `file_search`, or `function`.

properties.name: tool_resources
properties.description: A set of resources that are used by the assistant's tools. The resources are specific to the type of tool. For example, the `code_interpreter` tool requires a list of file IDs, while the `file_search` tool requires a list of vector store IDs.

properties.name: code_interpreter
properties.description: A set of resources that are used by the assistant's tools. The resources are specific to the type of tool. For example, the `code_interpreter` tool requires a list of file IDs, while the `file_search` tool requires a list of vector store IDs.

properties.name: file_ids
properties.description: A list of [file](/docs/api-reference/files) IDs made available to the `code_interpreter` tool. There can be a maximum of 20 files associated with the tool.

properties.name: file_search
properties.description: A set of resources that are used by the assistant's tools. The resources are specific to the type of tool. For example, the `code_interpreter` tool requires a list of file IDs, while the `file_search` tool requires a list of vector store IDs.

properties.name: vector_store_ids
properties.description: The [vector store](/docs/api-reference/vector-stores/object) attached to this assistant. There can be a maximum of 1 vector store attached to the assistant.

properties.name: vector_stores
properties.description: A helper to create a [vector store](/docs/api-reference/vector-stores/object) with file_ids and attach it to this assistant. There can be a maximum of 1 vector store attached to the assistant.

properties.name: file_ids
properties.description: A list of [file](/docs/api-reference/files) IDs to add to the vector store. There can be a maximum of 10000 files in a vector store.

properties.name: chunking_strategy
properties.description: The chunking strategy used to chunk the file(s). If not set, will use the `auto` strategy.

properties.name: metadata
properties.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. 

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

properties.name: metadata
properties.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. 

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

properties.name: temperature
properties.description: What sampling temperature to use, between 0 and 2. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic.

properties.name: top_p
properties.description:
An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.

We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

properties.name: response_format
properties.description:
Specifies the format that the model must output. Compatible with [GPT-4o](/docs/models#gpt-4o), [GPT-4 Turbo](/docs/models#gpt-4-turbo-and-gpt-4), and all GPT-3.5 Turbo models since `gpt-3.5-turbo-1106`.

Setting to `{ "type": "json_schema", "json_schema": {...} }` enables Structured Outputs which ensures the model will match your supplied JSON schema. Learn more in the [Structured Outputs guide](/docs/guides/structured-outputs).

Setting to `{ "type": "json_object" }` enables JSON mode, which ensures the message the model generates is valid JSON.

**Important:** when using JSON mode, you **must** also instruct the model to produce JSON yourself via a system or user message. Without this, the model may generate an unending stream of whitespace until the generation reaches the token limit, resulting in a long-running and seemingly "stuck" request. Also note that the message content may be partially cut off if `finish_reason="length"`, which indicates the generation exceeded `max_tokens` or the conversation exceeded the max context length.

title: Modify assistant
description:
---
group:
  - Assistants
---
Modifies an assistant.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/assistants/asst_abc123 \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "OpenAI-Beta: assistants=v2" \
  -d '{
      "instructions": "You are an HR bot, and you have access to files to answer employee questions about company policies. Always response with info from either of the files.",
      "tools": [{"type": "file_search"}],
      "model": "gpt-4o"
    }'

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

my_updated_assistant = client.beta.assistants.update(
  "asst_abc123",
  instructions="You are an HR bot, and you have access to files to answer employee questions about company policies. Always response with info from either of the files.",
  name="HR Helper",
  tools=[{"type": "file_search"}],
  model="gpt-4o"
)

print(my_updated_assistant)

tabs.title: js

properties.name: assistant_id
properties.description: The ID of the assistant to modify.

properties.name: model
properties.description: ID of the model to use. You can use the [List models](/docs/api-reference/models/list) API to see all of your available models, or see our [Model overview](/docs/models) for descriptions of them.

properties.name: reasoning_effort
properties.description:
**o-series models only** 

Constrains effort on reasoning for 
[reasoning models](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/reasoning).
Currently supported values are `low`, `medium`, and `high`. Reducing
reasoning effort can result in faster responses and fewer tokens used
on reasoning in a response.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The name of the assistant. The maximum length is 256 characters.

properties.name: description
properties.description: The description of the assistant. The maximum length is 512 characters.

properties.name: instructions
properties.description: The system instructions that the assistant uses. The maximum length is 256,000 characters.

properties.name: tools
properties.description: A list of tool enabled on the assistant. There can be a maximum of 128 tools per assistant. Tools can be of types `code_interpreter`, `file_search`, or `function`.

properties.name: tool_resources
properties.description: A set of resources that are used by the assistant's tools. The resources are specific to the type of tool. For example, the `code_interpreter` tool requires a list of file IDs, while the `file_search` tool requires a list of vector store IDs.

properties.name: code_interpreter
properties.description: A set of resources that are used by the assistant's tools. The resources are specific to the type of tool. For example, the `code_interpreter` tool requires a list of file IDs, while the `file_search` tool requires a list of vector store IDs.

properties.name: file_ids
properties.description: Overrides the list of [file](/docs/api-reference/files) IDs made available to the `code_interpreter` tool. There can be a maximum of 20 files associated with the tool.

properties.name: file_search
properties.description: A set of resources that are used by the assistant's tools. The resources are specific to the type of tool. For example, the `code_interpreter` tool requires a list of file IDs, while the `file_search` tool requires a list of vector store IDs.

properties.name: vector_store_ids
properties.description: Overrides the [vector store](/docs/api-reference/vector-stores/object) attached to this assistant. There can be a maximum of 1 vector store attached to the assistant.

properties.name: metadata
properties.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. 

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

properties.name: temperature
properties.description: What sampling temperature to use, between 0 and 2. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic.

properties.name: top_p
properties.description:
An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.

We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

properties.name: response_format
properties.description:
Specifies the format that the model must output. Compatible with [GPT-4o](/docs/models#gpt-4o), [GPT-4 Turbo](/docs/models#gpt-4-turbo-and-gpt-4), and all GPT-3.5 Turbo models since `gpt-3.5-turbo-1106`.

Setting to `{ "type": "json_schema", "json_schema": {...} }` enables Structured Outputs which ensures the model will match your supplied JSON schema. Learn more in the [Structured Outputs guide](/docs/guides/structured-outputs).

Setting to `{ "type": "json_object" }` enables JSON mode, which ensures the message the model generates is valid JSON.

**Important:** when using JSON mode, you **must** also instruct the model to produce JSON yourself via a system or user message. Without this, the model may generate an unending stream of whitespace until the generation reaches the token limit, resulting in a long-running and seemingly "stuck" request. Also note that the message content may be partially cut off if `finish_reason="length"`, which indicates the generation exceeded `max_tokens` or the conversation exceeded the max context length.

- `assistant`: Indicates the message is generated by the assistant. Use this value to insert messages from the assistant into the conversation.

title: The message object
description: Represents a message within a [thread](/docs/api-reference/threads).

properties.name: id
properties.description: The identifier, which can be referenced in API endpoints.

properties.name: object
properties.description: The object type, which is always `thread.message`.

properties.name: created_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the message was created.

properties.name: thread_id
properties.description: The [thread](/docs/api-reference/threads) ID that this message belongs to.

properties.name: status
properties.description: The status of the message, which can be either `in_progress`, `incomplete`, or `completed`.

properties.name: incomplete_details
properties.description: On an incomplete message, details about why the message is incomplete.

properties.name: reason
properties.description: The reason the message is incomplete.

properties.name: completed_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the message was completed.

properties.name: incomplete_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the message was marked as incomplete.

properties.name: role
properties.description: The entity that produced the message. One of `user` or `assistant`.

properties.name: content
properties.description: The content of the message in array of text and/or images.

properties.name: assistant_id
properties.description: If applicable, the ID of the [assistant](/docs/api-reference/assistants) that authored this message.

properties.name: run_id
properties.description: The ID of the [run](/docs/api-reference/runs) associated with the creation of this message. Value is `null` when messages are created manually using the create message or create thread endpoints.

properties.name: attachments
properties.description: A list of files attached to the message, and the tools they were added to.

properties.name: file_id
properties.description: The ID of the file to attach to the message.

properties.name: tools
properties.description: The tools to add this file to.

properties.name: metadata
properties.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. 

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

properties.name: thread_id
properties.description: The ID of the thread to run.

properties.name: include[]
properties.description:
A list of additional fields to include in the response. Currently the only supported value is `step_details.tool_calls[*].file_search.results[*].content` to fetch the file search result content.

See the [file search tool documentation](/docs/assistants/tools/file-search#customizing-file-search-settings) for more information.

properties.name: assistant_id
properties.description: The ID of the [assistant](/docs/api-reference/assistants) to use to execute this run.

properties.name: model
properties.description: The ID of the [Model](/docs/api-reference/models) to be used to execute this run. If a value is provided here, it will override the model associated with the assistant. If not, the model associated with the assistant will be used.

properties.name: reasoning_effort
properties.description:
**o-series models only** 

Constrains effort on reasoning for 
[reasoning models](https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/reasoning).
Currently supported values are `low`, `medium`, and `high`. Reducing
reasoning effort can result in faster responses and fewer tokens used
on reasoning in a response.

properties.name: instructions
properties.description: Overrides the [instructions](/docs/api-reference/assistants/createAssistant) of the assistant. This is useful for modifying the behavior on a per-run basis.

properties.name: additional_instructions
properties.description: Appends additional instructions at the end of the instructions for the run. This is useful for modifying the behavior on a per-run basis without overriding other instructions.

properties.name: additional_messages
properties.description: Adds additional messages to the thread before creating the run.

properties.name: role
properties.description:
The role of the entity that is creating the message. Allowed values include:
- `user`: Indicates the message is sent by an actual user and should be used in most cases to represent user-generated messages.
- `assistant`: Indicates the message is generated by the assistant. Use this value to insert messages from the assistant into the conversation.

properties.name: attachments
properties.description: A list of files attached to the message, and the tools they should be added to.

properties.name: file_id
properties.description: The ID of the file to attach to the message.

properties.name: tools
properties.description: The tools to add this file to.

properties.name: metadata
properties.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. 

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

properties.name: tools
properties.description: Override the tools the assistant can use for this run. This is useful for modifying the behavior on a per-run basis.

properties.name: metadata
properties.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. 

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

properties.name: temperature
properties.description: What sampling temperature to use, between 0 and 2. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic.

properties.name: top_p
properties.description:
An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.

We generally recommend altering this or temperature but not both.

properties.name: stream
properties.description: If `true`, returns a stream of events that happen during the Run as server-sent events, terminating when the Run enters a terminal state with a `data: [DONE]` message.

properties.name: max_prompt_tokens
properties.description: The maximum number of prompt tokens that may be used over the course of the run. The run will make a best effort to use only the number of prompt tokens specified, across multiple turns of the run. If the run exceeds the number of prompt tokens specified, the run will end with status `incomplete`. See `incomplete_details` for more info.

properties.name: max_completion_tokens
properties.description: The maximum number of completion tokens that may be used over the course of the run. The run will make a best effort to use only the number of completion tokens specified, across multiple turns of the run. If the run exceeds the number of completion tokens specified, the run will end with status `incomplete`. See `incomplete_details` for more info.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The truncation strategy to use for the thread. The default is `auto`. If set to `last_messages`, the thread will be truncated to the n most recent messages in the thread. When set to `auto`, messages in the middle of the thread will be dropped to fit the context length of the model, `max_prompt_tokens`.

properties.name: last_messages
properties.description: The number of most recent messages from the thread when constructing the context for the run.

properties.name: parallel_tool_calls
properties.description: Whether to enable [parallel function calling](/docs/guides/function-calling#configuring-parallel-function-calling) during tool use.

properties.name: response_format
properties.description:
Specifies the format that the model must output. Compatible with [GPT-4o](/docs/models#gpt-4o), [GPT-4 Turbo](/docs/models#gpt-4-turbo-and-gpt-4), and all GPT-3.5 Turbo models since `gpt-3.5-turbo-1106`.

Setting to `{ "type": "json_schema", "json_schema": {...} }` enables Structured Outputs which ensures the model will match your supplied JSON schema. Learn more in the [Structured Outputs guide](/docs/guides/structured-outputs).

Setting to `{ "type": "json_object" }` enables JSON mode, which ensures the message the model generates is valid JSON.

**Important:** when using JSON mode, you **must** also instruct the model to produce JSON yourself via a system or user message. Without this, the model may generate an unending stream of whitespace until the generation reaches the token limit, resulting in a long-running and seemingly "stuck" request. Also note that the message content may be partially cut off if `finish_reason="length"`, which indicates the generation exceeded `max_tokens` or the conversation exceeded the max context length.

title: List runs
description:
---
group:
  - Assistants
---
Returns a list of runs belonging to a thread.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/threads/thread_abc123/runs \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "OpenAI-Beta: assistants=v2"

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

runs = client.beta.threads.runs.list(
  "thread_abc123"
)

print(runs)

tabs.title: js

properties.name: thread_id
properties.description: The ID of the thread the run belongs to.

properties.name: limit
properties.description: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100, and the default is 20.

properties.name: order
properties.description: Sort order by the `created_at` timestamp of the objects. `asc` for ascending order and `desc` for descending order.

properties.name: after
properties.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `after` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, ending with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include after=obj_foo in order to fetch the next page of the list.

properties.name: before
properties.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `before` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, starting with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include before=obj_foo in order to fetch the previous page of the list.

title: Submit tool outputs to run
description:
---
group:
  - Assistants
---
When a run has the `status: "requires_action"` and `required_action.type` is `submit_tool_outputs`, this endpoint can be used to submit the outputs from the tool calls once they're all completed. All outputs must be submitted in a single request.

tabs.title: curl
python
node.js
curl
python
node.js

properties.name: thread_id
properties.description: The ID of the [thread](/docs/api-reference/threads) to which this run belongs.

properties.name: run_id
properties.description: The ID of the run that requires the tool output submission.

properties.name: tool_outputs
properties.description: A list of tools for which the outputs are being submitted.

properties.name: tool_call_id
properties.description: The ID of the tool call in the `required_action` object within the run object the output is being submitted for.

properties.name: output
properties.description: The output of the tool call to be submitted to continue the run.

properties.name: stream
properties.description: If `true`, returns a stream of events that happen during the Run as server-sent events, terminating when the Run enters a terminal state with a `data: [DONE]` message.

definitions.title: Response
definitions.description: The modified [run](/docs/api-reference/runs/object) object matching the specified ID.

tabs.code:

  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "OpenAI-Beta: assistants=v2" \

tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

title: The run object
description: Represents an execution run on a [thread](/docs/api-reference/threads).

properties.name: id
properties.description: The identifier, which can be referenced in API endpoints.

properties.name: object
properties.description: The object type, which is always `thread.run`.

properties.name: created_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the run was created.

properties.name: thread_id
properties.description: The ID of the [thread](/docs/api-reference/threads) that was executed on as a part of this run.

properties.name: assistant_id
properties.description: The ID of the [assistant](/docs/api-reference/assistants) used for execution of this run.

properties.name: status
properties.description: The status of the run, which can be either `queued`, `in_progress`, `requires_action`, `cancelling`, `cancelled`, `failed`, `completed`, `incomplete`, or `expired`.

properties.name: required_action
properties.description: Details on the action required to continue the run. Will be `null` if no action is required.

properties.name: type
properties.description: For now, this is always `submit_tool_outputs`.

properties.name: submit_tool_outputs
properties.description: Details on the tool outputs needed for this run to continue.

properties.name: tool_calls
properties.description: A list of the relevant tool calls.

properties.name: items
properties.description: Tool call objects

properties.name: id
properties.description: The ID of the tool call. This ID must be referenced when you submit the tool outputs in using the [Submit tool outputs to run](/docs/api-reference/runs/submitToolOutputs) endpoint.

properties.name: type
properties.description: The type of tool call the output is required for. For now, this is always `function`.

properties.name: function
properties.description: The function definition.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The name of the function.

properties.name: arguments
properties.description: The arguments that the model expects you to pass to the function.

properties.name: last_error
properties.description: The last error associated with this run. Will be `null` if there are no errors.

properties.name: code
properties.description: One of `server_error`, `rate_limit_exceeded`, or `invalid_prompt`.

properties.name: message
properties.description: A human-readable description of the error.

properties.name: expires_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the run will expire.

properties.name: started_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the run was started.

properties.name: cancelled_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the run was cancelled.

properties.name: failed_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the run failed.

properties.name: completed_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) for when the run was completed.

properties.name: incomplete_details
properties.description: Details on why the run is incomplete. Will be `null` if the run is not incomplete.

properties.name: reason
properties.description: The reason why the run is incomplete. This will point to which specific token limit was reached over the course of the run.

properties.name: model
properties.description: The model that the [assistant](/docs/api-reference/assistants) used for this run.

properties.name: instructions
properties.description: The instructions that the [assistant](/docs/api-reference/assistants) used for this run.

properties.name: tools
properties.description: The list of tools that the [assistant](/docs/api-reference/assistants) used for this run.

properties.name: metadata
properties.description:
Set of 16 key-value pairs that can be attached to an object. This can be
useful for storing additional information about the object in a structured
format, and querying for objects via API or the dashboard. 

Keys are strings with a maximum length of 64 characters. Values are strings
with a maximum length of 512 characters.

properties.name: usage
properties.description: Usage statistics related to the run. This value will be `null` if the run is not in a terminal state (i.e. `in_progress`, `queued`, etc.).

properties.name: completion_tokens
properties.description: Number of completion tokens used over the course of the run.

properties.name: prompt_tokens
properties.description: Number of prompt tokens used over the course of the run.

properties.name: total_tokens
properties.description: Total number of tokens used (prompt + completion).

properties.name: temperature
properties.description: The sampling temperature used for this run. If not set, defaults to 1.

properties.name: top_p
properties.description: The nucleus sampling value used for this run. If not set, defaults to 1.

properties.name: max_prompt_tokens
properties.description: The maximum number of prompt tokens specified to have been used over the course of the run.

properties.name: max_completion_tokens
properties.description: The maximum number of completion tokens specified to have been used over the course of the run.

properties.name: parallel_tool_calls
properties.description: Whether to enable [parallel function calling](/docs/guides/function-calling#configuring-parallel-function-calling) during tool use.

properties.name: response_format
properties.description:
Specifies the format that the model must output. Compatible with [GPT-4o](/docs/models#gpt-4o), [GPT-4 Turbo](/docs/models#gpt-4-turbo-and-gpt-4), and all GPT-3.5 Turbo models since `gpt-3.5-turbo-1106`.

Setting to `{ "type": "json_schema", "json_schema": {...} }` enables Structured Outputs which ensures the model will match your supplied JSON schema. Learn more in the [Structured Outputs guide](/docs/guides/structured-outputs).

Setting to `{ "type": "json_object" }` enables JSON mode, which ensures the message the model generates is valid JSON.

**Important:** when using JSON mode, you **must** also instruct the model to produce JSON yourself via a system or user message. Without this, the model may generate an unending stream of whitespace until the generation reaches the token limit, resulting in a long-running and seemingly "stuck" request. Also note that the message content may be partially cut off if `finish_reason="length"`, which indicates the generation exceeded `max_tokens` or the conversation exceeded the max context length.

title: List run steps
description:

  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "OpenAI-Beta: assistants=v2"

from openai import OpenAI

For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, starting with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include before=obj_foo in order to fetch the previous page of the list.

title: Assistant stream events
description:
Represents an event emitted when streaming a Run.

Each event in a server-sent events stream has an `event` and `data` property:

```
event: thread.created
data: {"id": "thread_123", "object": "thread", ...}
```

We emit events whenever a new object is created, transitions to a new state, or is being
streamed in parts (deltas). For example, we emit `thread.run.created` when a new run
is created, `thread.run.completed` when a run completes, and so on. When an Assistant chooses
to create a message during a run, we emit a `thread.message.created event`, a
`thread.message.in_progress` event, many `thread.message.delta` events, and finally a
`thread.message.completed` event.

We may add additional events over time, so we recommend handling unknown events gracefully
in your code. See the [Assistants API quickstart](/docs/assistants/overview) to learn how to
integrate the Assistants API with streaming.

  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_ADMIN_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json"

properties.name: limit
properties.description: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100, and the default is 20.

properties.name: after
properties.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `after` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, ending with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include after=obj_foo in order to fetch the next page of the list.

properties.name: include_archived
properties.description: If `true` returns all projects including those that have been `archived`. Archived projects are not included by default.

title: Create project

group:

---
Create a new project in the organization. Projects can be created and archived, but cannot be deleted.

tabs.code:

    "object": "organization.project",
    "name": "Project ABC",
    "created_at": 1711471533,
    "archived_at": null,
    "status": "active"
}

title: Create project user
description:

group:

---
Adds a user to the project. Users must already be members of the organization to be added to a project.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl -X POST https://api.openai.com/v1/organization/projects/proj_abc/users \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_ADMIN_KEY" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
      "user_id": "user_abc",
      "role": "member"
  }'

{
    "object": "organization.project.user",
    "id": "user_abc",
    "email": "user@example.com",
    "role": "owner",
    "added_at": 1711471533
}

For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, beginning with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include before=obj_foo in order to fetch the previous page of the list.

title: List audit logs
description:
---
group:
  - Audit Logs
---
List user actions and configuration changes within this organization.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/organization/audit_logs \
-H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_ADMIN_KEY" \
-H "Content-Type: application/json"

properties.name: effective_at
properties.description: Return only events whose `effective_at` (Unix seconds) is in this range.

properties.name: project_ids[]
properties.description: Return only events for these projects.

properties.name: event_types[]
properties.description: Return only events with a `type` in one of these values. For example, `project.created`. For all options, see the documentation for the [audit log object](/docs/api-reference/audit-logs/object).

properties.name: actor_ids[]
properties.description: Return only events performed by these actors. Can be a user ID, a service account ID, or an api key tracking ID.

properties.name: actor_emails[]
properties.description: Return only events performed by users with these emails.

properties.name: resource_ids[]
properties.description: Return only events performed on these targets. For example, a project ID updated.

properties.name: limit
properties.description: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100, and the default is 20.

properties.name: after
properties.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `after` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, ending with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include after=obj_foo in order to fetch the next page of the list.

properties.name: before
properties.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `before` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, starting with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include before=obj_foo in order to fetch the previous page of the list.

title: Completions
description:
---
group:
  - Usage
---
Get completions usage details for the organization.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl "https://api.openai.com/v1/organization/usage/completions?start_time=1730419200&limit=1" \
-H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_ADMIN_KEY" \
-H "Content-Type: application/json"

{
    "object": "page",
    "data": [
        {
            "object": "bucket",
            "start_time": 1730419200,
            "end_time": 1730505600,
            "results": [
                {
                    "object": "organization.usage.completions.result",
                    "input_tokens": 1000,
                    "output_tokens": 500,
                    "input_cached_tokens": 800,
                    "input_audio_tokens": 0,
                    "output_audio_tokens": 0,
                    "num_model_requests": 5,
                    "project_id": null,
                    "user_id": null,
                    "api_key_id": null,
                    "model": null,
                    "batch": null
                }
            ]
        }
    ],
    "has_more": true,
    "next_page": "page_AAAAAGdGxdEiJdKOAAAAAGcqsYA="
}

properties.name: start_time
properties.description: Start time (Unix seconds) of the query time range, inclusive.

properties.name: end_time
properties.description: End time (Unix seconds) of the query time range, exclusive.

properties.name: bucket_width
properties.description: Width of each time bucket in response. Currently `1m`, `1h` and `1d` are supported, default to `1d`.

properties.name: project_ids
properties.description: Return only usage for these projects.

properties.name: user_ids
properties.description: Return only usage for these users.

properties.name: api_key_ids
properties.description: Return only usage for these API keys.

properties.name: models
properties.description: Return only usage for these models.

properties.name: batch
properties.description: If `true`, return batch jobs only. If `false`, return non-batch jobs only. By default, return both.

properties.name: group_by
properties.description: Group the usage data by the specified fields. Support fields include `project_id`, `user_id`, `api_key_id`, `model`, `batch` or any combination of them.

properties.name: limit
properties.description:
Specifies the number of buckets to return.
- `bucket_width=1d`: default: 7, max: 31
- `bucket_width=1h`: default: 24, max: 168
- `bucket_width=1m`: default: 60, max: 1440

properties.name: page
properties.description: A cursor for use in pagination. Corresponding to the `next_page` field from the previous response.

definitions.title: Response
definitions.description: A list of paginated, time bucketed [Completions usage](/docs/api-reference/usage/completions_object) objects.

title: Completions usage object
description: The aggregated completions usage details of the specific time bucket.

properties.name: input_tokens
properties.description: The aggregated number of text input tokens used, including cached tokens. For customers subscribe to scale tier, this includes scale tier tokens.

properties.name: input_cached_tokens
properties.description: The aggregated number of text input tokens that has been cached from previous requests. For customers subscribe to scale tier, this includes scale tier tokens.

properties.name: output_tokens
properties.description: The aggregated number of text output tokens used. For customers subscribe to scale tier, this includes scale tier tokens.

properties.name: input_audio_tokens
properties.description: The aggregated number of audio input tokens used, including cached tokens.

properties.name: output_audio_tokens
properties.description: The aggregated number of audio output tokens used.

properties.name: num_model_requests
properties.description: The count of requests made to the model.

properties.name: project_id
properties.description: When `group_by=project_id`, this field provides the project ID of the grouped usage result.

properties.name: user_id
properties.description: When `group_by=user_id`, this field provides the user ID of the grouped usage result.

properties.name: api_key_id
properties.description: When `group_by=api_key_id`, this field provides the API key ID of the grouped usage result.

properties.name: model
properties.description: When `group_by=model`, this field provides the model name of the grouped usage result.

properties.name: batch
properties.description: When `group_by=batch`, this field tells whether the grouped usage result is batch or not.

title: Upload certificate
description:
---
group:
  - Certificates
---
Upload a certificate to the organization. This does **not** automatically activate the certificate.

Organizations can upload up to 50 certificates.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl -X POST https://api.openai.com/v1/organization/certificates \
-H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_ADMIN_KEY" \
-H "Content-Type: application/json" \
-d '{
  "name": "My Example Certificate",
  "certificate": "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----\\nMIIDeT...\\n-----END CERTIFICATE-----"
}'

properties.name: name
properties.description: An optional name for the certificate

properties.name: content
properties.description: The certificate content in PEM format

title: Get certificate
description:
---
group:
  - Certificates
---
Get a certificate that has been uploaded to the organization.

You can get a certificate regardless of whether it is active or not.

tabs.title: bash
tabs.code:
curl "https://api.openai.com/v1/organization/certificates/cert_abc?include[]=content" \
-H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_ADMIN_KEY"

properties.name: cert_id
properties.description: Unique ID of the certificate to retrieve.

properties.name: include
properties.description: A list of additional fields to include in the response. Currently the only supported value is `content` to fetch the PEM content of the certificate.

Delete a certificate from the organization.

The certificate must be inactive for the organization and all projects.

curl -X DELETE https://api.openai.com/v1/organization/certificates/cert_abc \
-H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_ADMIN_KEY"

definitions.title: Response

title: List organization certificates

curl https://api.openai.com/v1/organization/certificates \
-H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_ADMIN_KEY"

properties.name: limit
properties.description: A limit on the number of objects to be returned. Limit can range between 1 and 100, and the default is 20.

properties.name: after
properties.description: A cursor for use in pagination. `after` is an object ID that defines your place in the list. For instance, if you make a list request and receive 100 objects, ending with obj_foo, your subsequent call can include after=obj_foo in order to fetch the next page of the list.

properties.name: order
properties.description: Sort order by the `created_at` timestamp of the objects. `asc` for ascending order and `desc` for descending order.

title: The certificate object
description: Represents an individual `certificate` uploaded to the organization.

properties.name: object
properties.description:
The object type.

- If creating, updating, or getting a specific certificate, the object type is `certificate`.
- If listing, activating, or deactivating certificates for the organization, the object type is `organization.certificate`.
- If listing, activating, or deactivating certificates for a project, the object type is `organization.project.certificate`.

properties.name: id
properties.description: The identifier, which can be referenced in API endpoints

properties.name: name
properties.description: The name of the certificate.

properties.name: created_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) of when the certificate was uploaded.

properties.name: valid_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) of when the certificate becomes valid.

properties.name: expires_at
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) of when the certificate expires.

properties.name: content
properties.description: The content of the certificate in PEM format.

properties.name: active
properties.description: Whether the certificate is currently active at the specified scope. Not returned when getting details for a specific certificate.

title: Create completion
description:
---
group:
  - Completions
---
Creates a completion for the provided prompt and parameters.

tabs.title: curl
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/completions \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -d '{
    "model": "VAR_completion_model_id",
    "prompt": "Say this is a test",
    "max_tokens": 7,
    "temperature": 0
  }'

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

client.completions.create(
  model="VAR_completion_model_id",
  prompt="Say this is a test",
  max_tokens=7,
  temperature=0
)

tabs.title: node.js
curl
tabs.code:
curl https://api.openai.com/v1/completions \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer $OPENAI_API_KEY" \
  -d '{
    "model": "VAR_completion_model_id",
    "prompt": "Say this is a test",
    "max_tokens": 7,
    "temperature": 0,
    "stream": true
  }'

tabs.title: python
tabs.code:
from openai import OpenAI
client = OpenAI()

for chunk in client.completions.create(
  model="VAR_completion_model_id",
  prompt="Say this is a test",
  max_tokens=7,
  temperature=0,
  stream=True
):
  print(chunk.choices[0].text)

tabs.title: node.js

properties.name: model
properties.description: ID of the model to use. You can use the [List models](/docs/api-reference/models/list) API to see all of your available models, or see our [Model overview](/docs/models) for descriptions of them.

properties.name: prompt
properties.description:
The prompt(s) to generate completions for, encoded as a string, array of strings, array of tokens, or array of token arrays.

Note that <|endoftext|> is the document separator that the model sees during training, so if a prompt is not specified the model will generate as if from the beginning of a new document.

properties.name: best_of
properties.description:
Generates `best_of` completions server-side and returns the "best" (the one with the highest log probability per token). Results cannot be streamed.

When used with `n`, `best_of` controls the number of candidate completions and `n` specifies how many to return – `best_of` must be greater than `n`.

**Note:** Because this parameter generates many completions, it can quickly consume your token quota. Use carefully and ensure that you have reasonable settings for `max_tokens` and `stop`.

properties.name: echo
properties.description: Echo back the prompt in addition to the completion

properties.name: frequency_penalty
properties.description:
Number between -2.0 and 2.0. Positive values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model's likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim.

[See more information about frequency and presence penalties.](/docs/guides/text-generation)

properties.name: logit_bias
properties.description:
Modify the likelihood of specified tokens appearing in the completion.

Accepts a JSON object that maps tokens (specified by their token ID in the GPT tokenizer) to an associated bias value from -100 to 100. You can use this [tokenizer tool](/tokenizer?view=bpe) to convert text to token IDs. Mathematically, the bias is added to the logits generated by the model prior to sampling. The exact effect will vary per model, but values between -1 and 1 should decrease or increase likelihood of selection; values like -100 or 100 should result in a ban or exclusive selection of the relevant token.

As an example, you can pass `{"50256": -100}` to prevent the <|endoftext|> token from being generated.

properties.name: logprobs
properties.description:
Include the log probabilities on the `logprobs` most likely output tokens, as well the chosen tokens. For example, if `logprobs` is 5, the API will return a list of the 5 most likely tokens. The API will always return the `logprob` of the sampled token, so there may be up to `logprobs+1` elements in the response.

The maximum value for `logprobs` is 5.

properties.name: max_tokens
properties.description:
The maximum number of [tokens](/tokenizer) that can be generated in the completion.

The token count of your prompt plus `max_tokens` cannot exceed the model's context length. [Example Python code](https://cookbook.openai.com/examples/how_to_count_tokens_with_tiktoken) for counting tokens.

properties.name: n
properties.description:
How many completions to generate for each prompt.

**Note:** Because this parameter generates many completions, it can quickly consume your token quota. Use carefully and ensure that you have reasonable settings for `max_tokens` and `stop`.

properties.name: presence_penalty
properties.description:
Number between -2.0 and 2.0. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model's likelihood to talk about new topics.

[See more information about frequency and presence penalties.](/docs/guides/text-generation)

properties.name: seed
properties.description:
If specified, our system will make a best effort to sample deterministically, such that repeated requests with the same `seed` and parameters should return the same result.

Determinism is not guaranteed, and you should refer to the `system_fingerprint` response parameter to monitor changes in the backend.

properties.name: stop
properties.description:
Not supported with latest reasoning models `o3` and `o4-mini`.

Up to 4 sequences where the API will stop generating further tokens. The
returned text will not contain the stop sequence.

properties.name: stream
properties.description: Whether to stream back partial progress. If set, tokens will be sent as data-only [server-sent events](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Server-sent_events/Using_server-sent_events#Event_stream_format) as they become available, with the stream terminated by a `data: [DONE]` message. [Example Python code](https://cookbook.openai.com/examples/how_to_stream_completions).

properties.name: stream_options
properties.description: Options for streaming response. Only set this when you set `stream: true`.

properties.name: include_usage
properties.description:
If set, an additional chunk will be streamed before the `data: [DONE]`
message. The `usage` field on this chunk shows the token usage statistics
for the entire request, and the `choices` field will always be an empty
array. 

All other chunks will also include a `usage` field, but with a null
value. **NOTE:** If the stream is interrupted, you may not receive the
final usage chunk which contains the total token usage for the request.

properties.name: suffix
properties.description:
The suffix that comes after a completion of inserted text.

This parameter is only supported for `gpt-3.5-turbo-instruct`.

properties.name: temperature
properties.description:
What sampling temperature to use, between 0 and 2. Higher values like 0.8 will make the output more random, while lower values like 0.2 will make it more focused and deterministic.

We generally recommend altering this or `top_p` but not both.

properties.name: top_p
properties.description:
An alternative to sampling with temperature, called nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top_p probability mass. So 0.1 means only the tokens comprising the top 10% probability mass are considered.

We generally recommend altering this or `temperature` but not both.

properties.name: user
properties.description: A unique identifier representing your end-user, which can help OpenAI to monitor and detect abuse. [Learn more](/docs/guides/safety-best-practices#end-user-ids).

definitions.title: Response
definitions.description: Returns a [completion](/docs/api-reference/completions/object) object, or a sequence of completion objects if the request is streamed.

title: The completion object
description: Represents a completion response from the API. Note: both the streamed and non-streamed response objects share the same shape (unlike the chat endpoint).

properties.name: id
properties.description: A unique identifier for the completion.

properties.name: choices
properties.description: The list of completion choices the model generated for the input prompt.

properties.name: finish_reason
properties.description:
The reason the model stopped generating tokens. This will be `stop` if the model hit a natural stop point or a provided stop sequence,
`length` if the maximum number of tokens specified in the request was reached,
or `content_filter` if content was omitted due to a flag from our content filters.

properties.name: created
properties.description: The Unix timestamp (in seconds) of when the completion was created.

properties.name: model
properties.description: The model used for completion.

properties.name: system_fingerprint
properties.description:
This fingerprint represents the backend configuration that the model runs with.

Can be used in conjunction with the `seed` request parameter to understand when backend changes have been made that might impact determinism.

properties.name: object
properties.description: The object type, which is always "text_completion"

properties.name: usage
properties.description: Usage statistics for the completion request.

properties.name: completion_tokens
properties.description: Number of tokens in the generated completion.

properties.name: prompt_tokens
properties.description: Number of tokens in the prompt.

properties.name: total_tokens
properties.description: Total number of tokens used in the request (prompt + completion).

properties.name: completion_tokens_details
properties.description: Breakdown of tokens used in a completion.

properties.name: accepted_prediction_tokens
properties.description:
When using Predicted Outputs, the number of tokens in the
prediction that appeared in the completion.

properties.name: audio_tokens
properties.description: Audio input tokens generated by the model.

properties.name: reasoning_tokens
properties.description: Tokens generated by the model for reasoning.

properties.name: rejected_prediction_tokens
properties.description:
When using Predicted Outputs, the number of tokens in the
prediction that did not appear in the completion. However, like
reasoning tokens, these tokens are still counted in the total
completion tokens for purposes of billing, output, and context window
limits.

properties.name: prompt_tokens_details
properties.description: Breakdown of tokens used in the prompt.

properties.name: audio_tokens
properties.description: Audio input tokens present in the prompt.

properties.name: cached_tokens
properties.description: Cached tokens present in the prompt.
